Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46309-001 
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
 
Supporting Regional Project Development for 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations Connectivity 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
AEC  –  ASEAN Economic Community 
  AIF  –  ASEAN Infrastructure Fund 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  MPAC  –  Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity 
  PPP  –  public−private partnership 
  TA  –  technical assistance

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)1 are committed 
to  regional  economic  integration.  Foremost,  they  are  committed  to  the  realization  of  the 
ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) by 2015. In an important step toward achieving this goal, 
ASEAN leaders issued the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity (MPAC) in 2010 to promote 
infrastructure  development  and  connectivity.  As  intraregional  trade  and  investment  flows 
increase, the region's infrastructure needs to keep pace. This is based on a clear recognition 
that, to better connect the regional market of 600 million people spread across 10 different 
countries, an infrastructure development-driven connectivity is key. In addition, the regional 
and subregional sector analyses have confirmed the importance of maintaining economic 
corridor connectivity in the drive to realize the AEC. 
 
2.  ASEAN and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) have been collaborating on various 
initiatives required to support the implementation of the MPAC. An important one is the recent 
establishment of the ASEAN Infrastructure Fund (AIF).2 The AIF (with mandatory cofinancing 
from  ADB)  can  provide  financing  for  key  infrastructure  projects  to  promote  connectivity. 
However, even with the AIF, additional support is needed to ensure that the priority projects 
are properly screened and made viable for private sector participation.3 Given the high overall 
financing requirements (estimated to be around $60 billion per year for ASEAN) and the 
limited supply of financing, projects need to be prioritized based on their expected impact and 
viability. To assist in this task, the regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
has  been  designed  in  consultation  with  ASEAN  members.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.4 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Need for project processing and development. Given the large infrastructure needs 
in the region, there is no dearth of projects, including those that foster connectivity. However, 
the region as a whole has been less successful in making those projects bankable enough to be 
able to attract funded risk participation from the private sector.5 Thus, while the region is 
becoming  more  integrated  and  steady  progress  has  been  made  on  various  facets  of 
connectivity, significant work is required to screen projects prior to their preparation to maximize 
their chances of securing private sector participation. Sequentially, the following tasks need to 
be undertaken in a systematic manner: 
 
                                                
1  ASEAN has the following members: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam. The ASEAN region also 
receives  support  from  three  key  subregional  programs:  (i)  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion;  (ii)  the  Brunei 
Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines  East  ASEAN  Growth  Area,  and  (iii)  the  Indonesia–Malaysia–
Thailand Growth Triangle. 
2  ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Equity Contribution 
and Administration of ASEAN Infrastructure Fund. Manila (16 September). The AIF is established by ASEAN 
member  countries  (except  Myanmar)  and  ADB  to  mobilize  financial  resources  to  support  infrastructure 
development in the region. The shareholders’ agreement was signed on 24 September 2011 in Washington, DC. 
As of 15 November 2012, the AIF is considered to be operational, and will begin to lend around $300 million per 
year, starting in 2013.   
3  The AIF is administered by ADB, and ADB is responsible for all aspects of its operations, including project pipeline 
formulation, project preparation, and implementation. In the first 5 years of operations, the AIF can only provide 
financing for sovereign projects. However, it can also provide financing for the public portion of public–private 
partnership (PPP) projects. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 September 2012. 
5  The financing challenges are discussed in greater detail in the AIF report cited in footnote 2.

2   
(i)  A set of robust screening criteria needs to be developed to assess prospects for 
(a) the public–private partnership (PPP) modality (with funded risk participation6 
by the private sector) and (b) the fostering of regional connectivity. 
(ii)  The projects that meet the criteria need to be identified, then screened and 
prioritized for further development. 
(iii)  Based on the project screening studies, detailed structuring plans need to be 
prepared, focusing on technical, financial, legal, and procurement aspects. 
(iv)  Preliminary investment and financing plans need to be prepared based on initial 
risk assessment and likely sources of financing, including the AIF. 
(v)  Information memoranda need to be produced that highlight the prospects for 
private investors and indicate the type and quantum of public sector support.7 
 
4.  While  the  MPAC  and  other  plans8  have  defined  priority  project  concepts  to  foster 
connectivity, there is a need to develop a viable project pipeline, which is based on a systematic 
approach for initial due diligence. In addition, the screening of the projects should ascertain 
whether they could be financed by such new initiatives as the AIF or by private investments 
through the PPP modality. Specifically, the following tasks are required:  
 
(i)  Although the AIF is designed to help mobilize public and private resources for 
infrastructure financing, specific support is required for project screening. This is 
because, while the AIF will have ADB cofinancing for all projects, the project 
scope and other details need to be consistent with AIF design and objectives. To 
the  extent  possible,  the  effort  should  focus  on  the  key  strategic  projects  to 
promote connectivity, including those specified in the MPAC. 
(ii)  While  ADB  and  the  AIF  can  continue  to  provide  financing  to  governments, 
additional measures are needed to  boost private sector participation for key 
regional infrastructure development.9 Even as the region has been active in 
fostering private participation in infrastructure nationally, a mechanism is required 
to catalyze additional private investments into projects that promote regional 
connectivity. Since ADB has various public sector projects that lend themselves 
to PPP, for those with regional impact, ADB and the AIF can finance the public 
portion while helping structure the portion that is to be financed privately. 
 
                                                
6  This distinction is critical to classify projects according to various forms of private sector engagement, from 
management contract to leasing to a proper concession. The nature and prospects will vary across the various 
infrastructure sectors and countries. 
7  Depending on the risk management frameworks in the country concerned, the team involved in screening needs to 
liaise closely with the authorities concerned to understand the criteria for determining public support for projects. 
8  This includes the implementation blueprints for the Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East 
ASEAN Growth Area and the Indonesia–Malaysia–Thailand Growth Triangle, endorsed at their respective senior 
officials summits in April 2012. The Greater Mekong Subregion leaders have also endorsed the 2012–2022 
Greater Mekong Subregion Strategic Framework, which focuses on investment projects that promote economic 
corridors, urban development, better transport and trade facilitation, and greater competitiveness. 
9  According to the World Bank’s database on private participation in infrastructure, the less-developed ASEAN 
members (Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, and Viet Nam) have received only around 
1% of the world’s total private investments during the 1990-2010 period (around $1 billion per year). Furthermore, 
since the capital market is mostly underdeveloped in the region, many ASEAN countries continue to rely on short-
term bank loans for infrastructure financing.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The overall impact of the TA is greater connectivity in the ASEAN region. While there are 
many  facets  to  connectivity,  this  TA  will  concentrate  on  the  region’s  physical  connectivity 
through infrastructure development. The TA will further aim to leverage on existing ASEAN-led 
initiatives (such as the AIF), and step up efforts to encourage private sector involvement through 
promoting PPP development. 
 
6.  The outcome of the TA is increased investments from both public and private sectors 
into ASEAN’s physical connectivity. The TA will develop a set of screening mechanisms to 
(i) determine the most viable projects with regional connectivity impact to be financed by ADB 
and the AIF, and (ii) catalyze private sector investments by developing a project structuring 
facility10 for regional PPP projects. For the PPP structuring, the targeted projects will be those 
included in the ADB pipeline, to be financed by ADB and the AIF. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  and  monitored  through  regular  reports,  dissemination 
activities  and  workshops,  and  feedback  obtained  through  periodic  consultations  with 
stakeholders. A series of smaller seminars can also be held in coordination with government 
agencies and other ADB departments (including the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department). Available updates, outputs, or observations will be discussed. The TA will deliver 
the following main outputs: 
 
(i)  Component 1: Project pipeline screening. In 2011, ADB approved the TA for 
the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity Implementation.11 Among its various 
components,  that  TA  supports  the  development  of  a  pipeline  of  regional 
connectivity projects. Building from those efforts, and based on the initial project 
pipeline for the AIF, this TA will engage in more in-depth project screening in 
coordination with the relevant sector divisions within the ADB Southeast Asia 
Department to further advance project financing. This component will carry out 
the  tasks  outlined  in  para.  3,  i.e.,  based  on  a  need  to  develop  a  sound 
infrastructure project pipeline with a regional scope to promote connectivity. The 
screened and selected projects should be financed by ADB and the AIF. 
(ii)  Component 2: Regional PPP structuring facility. In 2011, ADB was requested 
by the ASEAN Working Committee on Capital Market Development to study 
various options for PPP and capital market instruments for project financing. 
Accordingly,  ADB’s  TA  for  the  Promotion  of  Capital  Market  Instruments  for 
Infrastructure Financing in the ASEAN was  undertaken to determine, among 
others, the necessity of and the processes involved in the development of a 
project  structuring  facility  focusing  on  the  key  infrastructure  projects  in  the 
ASEAN region. 12 Based on the study, ADB has undertaken consultations with 
Singapore (as a shareholder of the AIF seeking to promote PPP through AIF 
                                                
10 This is commonly described as a “project development facility”. For this TA, however, it is called “project structuring 
facility”. This distinction is made since the aim is to fully structure the projects for PPP financing. 
11 ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance for the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity Implementation. Manila (TA 8040-
REG, approved on 15 December). 
12 ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance for the Promotion of Capital Market Instruments for Infrastructure Financing in 
the ASEAN. Manila (TA 7969-REG, approved on 6 December).

4   
support, and as the chair of the ASEAN Working Committee on Capital Market 
Development) to support the facility.13 As such a facility will require considerable 
resources, ADB and the Government of Singapore have formulated a 3-year 
financing  plan  for  the  facility.  ADB  will  seek  additional  cofinanciers  and/or 
partners to support this initiative in the future (footnote 12). 
 
8.  The main link between the two components is as follows. The TA will initiate a project 
screening process to determine the most viable projects for further processing and project 
preparation. For those that are suitable for private financing (under the PPP modality), the 
facility will support the structuring work. Overall, the facility is designed to target PPP projects in 
the ADB project pipeline for which the public portion could be financed by ADB and the AIF; at 
the same time, the facility will catalyze private investments through its structuring work. In 
addition, the facility will need to coordinate with, and take into account the lessons learned from, 
the national facilities that already exist in the Southeast Asia region, such as those in Indonesia, 
the Philippines, and Viet Nam. For more effective use of capital market instruments, the facility 
could seek synergy with the existing institutions and initiatives, such as the Credit Guarantee 
Investment Facility.14 
 
9.  The proposed facility will be financed by both ADB and Singapore. A steering committee 
made up of Singaporean and ADB officials will oversee it.15 ADB will endeavor to find suitable 
projects for the facility, i.e., those that (i) have sufficient size for PPP structuring, (ii) have 
substantial impact on the region, and (iii) can be financed by ADB and the AIF. After the 
recommendation from ADB, the facility can conduct short screening studies to determine the 
most suitable projects (through the TA’s component 1). Then, the PPP structuring work will 
begin for a given project; it is envisioned that it will take 2–3 years to complete the structuring. 
 
10.  Based on the above design and expected outputs, the major assumptions for the TA are: 
(i) continued commitment for narrowing the development gap is a shared goal of all ASEAN 
developing member countries, (ii) there is sustained private sector interest in infrastructure 
development  in  ASEAN,  and  (iii)  ASEAN-wide  objectives  continue  to  be  reflected  in  and 
consistent with national plans of ASEAN developing member countries. Major risks are: (i) a 
prolonged economic downturn could lead to a policy shift toward domestic economic concerns, 
(ii) policy shifts result in reluctance of the relevant agencies to share undertakings in specific 
areas for a sustained period of time, and (iii) Asia’s private sector participation is adversely 
affected by economic conditions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,200,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The resource support from Singapore (as 
                                                
13 The facility (tentatively called the ASEAN Infrastructure Center of Excellence) will be supported by ADB through 
this TA and other resource allocation. This does not require an equity investment from ADB. The support of the 
Government of Singapore for the facility will be provided on an untied, parallel, and equal basis. The commitment 
of the Government of Singapore will be around $4.5 million for 3 years (or $1.5 million per year). Based on the 
progress and requirements, ADB and the Government of Singapore could seek additional financial support for the 
proposed facility from other development partners. 
14 Further information on the Credit Guarantee Investment Facility may be obtained from:  
http://www.adb.org/site/funds/funds/credit-guarantee-and-investment-facility 
15 In August 2012, the ADB Management approved the formation of an interdepartmental team to work on the facility. 
It  consists  of  ADB’s  Southeast  Asia  Department  (PPP  Unit  and  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operation 
Coordination  Division)  and  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  (Sustainable  Infrastructure 
Division), and the PPP community of practice (as advisor).

5 
explained above) will be undertaken in parallel.16 The TA is expected to undertake Component 
1 (which is estimated to be around $150,000), while Component 2 will be undertaken with 
Singapore. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB—through  its  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations  Coordination  Division,  the 
Southeast Asia Department as a focal point, and with participation from other ADB departments 
(including the Regional and Sustainable Development Department)—will implement the TA over 
36 months, from January 2013 to January 2016. The Regional Cooperation and Operations 
Coordination Division will coordinate with the Southeast Asia Department's sector divisions and 
resident missions on TA findings. ADB will coordinate with ASEAN and its initiatives, including 
the AIF. As the TA involves PPP structuring, it will also seek support and advice from the ADB 
community of practice on PPP. When the TA is to engage in specific, in-country activities, 
concurrence from the respective government should be sought before starting those activities. 
In  addition,  a  steering  committee  consisting  of  ADB  and  Government  of  Singapore  staff 
members will be established to operate the proposed project structuring facility. 
 
13.  A group of individual consultants (and firms as appropriate)17 will provide the advisory, 
technical,  and  administrative  support  services.  It  is  estimated  that  36  person-months  of 
international and 36 person-months of national consulting services are required for the TA. Due 
to the diverse skills requirements, consultants will be engaged on an individual basis for the 
component  on  project  pipeline  screening,  and  through  a  firm  for  the  component  on  PPP 
structuring. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  As  required,  ADB  staff  members  will 
participate as resource persons where applicable. 
 
14.  The purchase of equipment (computer hardware and software) will be carried out in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and in 
coordination  with  the  ADB  Office  of  Information  Systems  and  Technology,  and  Office  of 
Administrative Services, where applicable. Upon TA completion, any procured equipment will be 
turned  over  to  the  developing  member  countries’  participating  government  agencies  in 
accordance with the relevant ADB's guidelines. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis 
for the Supporting Regional Project Development for Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
 
Connectivity, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
                                                
16 Accordingly, it is envisioned that a formal letter of agreement or memorandum of understanding will be signed with 
Singapore to outline the collaboration arrangement. 
17 The quality-based selection process will be used. The quality-based selection process has been recommended 
due to the complex nature of structuring PPP projects. Other methods of recruitment are to be tailored for this TA in 
consultation with the relevant departments in ADB.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Based on the progress and the scope of the selected projects, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) will provide a detailed set of milestones as the key success and performance 
criteria for the consultants.1 
 
A.  Output 1: Project Pipeline Development (individual consultants) 
1.  Infrastructure Specialists (international, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  A group of individual international specialists will be recruited to conduct a series of 
analyses  and  prefeasibility  studies  on key  projects for  the  purpose  of  pipeline  formulation 
(project screening) for the ASEAN Infrastructure Fund. Preferably, the infrastructure specialist 
should have 15 years of experience in relevant fields, with a relevant degree (e.g., engineering, 
economics). 
 
3.  The specialists will receive feedback and guidance from ADB and other development 
partners, and the national consultants will further support them. The studies to be carried out will 
include analysis of the potential projects to be included in the ASEAN Infrastructure Fund 
pipeline, and the specialists need to provide an overall viability assessment of public–private 
partnership (PPP) structuring. Detailed terms of reference will be drafted based on the technical 
assistance  (TA)  progress  and  recommendations  from  the  sector  divisions  within  the  ADB 
Southeast Asia Department. 
 
4.  The consultants will submit reports as per the terms of reference, e.g., (i) inception 
reports outlining initial findings, (ii) interim progress reports as necessary that detail further 
findings and preliminary recommendations, and (iii) a final report incorporating comments based 
on the draft final report. Additional output requirements will be determined based on need and 
TA progress. 
 
2.  Infrastructure Specialists (national, 6 person-months) 
 
5.  A group of individual national specialists will be recruited to assist the international 
infrastructure specialists in all aspects of the TA. Preferably, the infrastructure specialists should 
have  10  years  of  experience  in  relevant  fields,  with  a  relevant  degree  (e.g.,  engineering, 
economics). The consultants’ tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Under the guidance  of  the  international  infrastructure  specialists,  collect  and 
analyze  required  information  and  data  in  an  organized  form,  and  conduct 
research on specific topics. 
(ii)  Undertake  the  work  related  to  the  overall  administrative  and  organizational 
aspects of the TA team's operations. 
(iii)  Help the international consultants with their tasks, including providing inputs to 
and assisting the preparation of final reports, as necessary. 
(iv)  Arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the international 
consultants in preparing materials for such workshops. 
 
B.  Output  2:  Regional  PPP  Structuring  Facility  (firm:  international  and  national, 
30 person-months each) 
                                                
1  These consultants will be combined with those recruited by the Government of Singapore on a parallel basis.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
6.  A group  of  international  and  national  specialists  will  be  recruited  through  a firm to 
operate the PPP structuring initiative. The group will receive feedback and guidance from ADB 
and  other  development  partners.  Contracts  should  be  lump-sum,  performance-based,  and 
require adjustments during implementation. 
 
7.  The specific positions for this component will include: (i) team leader and international 
infrastructure financing specialist (10 person-months), (ii) international legal advisor (8 person-
months), and (iii) other international infrastructure financing and PPP specialists as required for 
selected projects (12 person-months). National consultants will also be recruited. Their positions 
will mirror those of the international consultants. Preferably, the consultants have 10 years of 
experience in relevant fields, with a relevant degree (e.g., finance). 
 
8.  Two groups of consultants will be recruited to support the work of the proposed facility.2 
Collectively, and under the guidance of ADB and other development partners, the major tasks 
include:  
 
1.  Facility’s Core Team Members 
9.  The infrastructure financing specialist (10 person-months) will do the following: 
(i)  Based  on  the  outputs  of  the  screening  studies,  support  ADB  and  others  to 
determine the most suitable projects to be structured by the facility. 
(ii)  Support the selection and recruitment of the project teams (including required 
skills sets) and provide inputs to their work program. 
(iii)  Facilitate  effective  synergy  and  partnerships  between  ADB,  Singaporean 
institutions and the regional initiatives to support the facility’s operations. 
(iv)  Support ADB in the dialogue with the governments, private sector, and other 
stakeholders in relation to the PPP structuring. 
(v)  Recommend the future direction of the facility’s operations based on operational 
experience of around 3 years. 
 
10.  The legal advisor (8 person-months) will do the following: 
(i)  Provide  legal  assessments  of  the  countries  in  which  the  PPP  work  will  be 
undertaken to highlight major issues associated with the structuring work. 
(ii)  Work with the project team members to ensure legal consistency between the 
project structuring work and the legal framework of the country. 
(iii)  Provide guidance and technical inputs to ensure that any documents (including 
bidding documents, and procurement plans) produced by the project team are on 
a sound legal basis. 
(iv)  Support ADB in the dialogue with the governments, private sector, and other 
stakeholders in relation to legal aspects of the PPP structuring. 
(v)  Recommend the future direction of the facility’s operations based on operational 
experience of around 3 years. 
 
                                                
2  Overall, the core team members will support ADB to administer the facility in general, while the project team will 
work on the specific projects.

Appendix 3  11 
2.  Facility’s Project Structuring Team Members (12 person-months) 
11.  The team members will do the following: 
(i)  Work with ADB and the governments to verify (a) study of demand and supply 
options  (i.e.,  services  to  be  delivered);  (b)  preliminary  technical  design  and 
specifications of the project; (c) cost estimates and financing plan; (d) social and 
environmental impact analysis; (e) economic and financial analysis, including 
tariff analysis and testing for project robustness (along with legal assessments). 
(ii)  Analyze prospective financing options pertinent to the project and the country in 
which the project is taking place, and develop a conceptual financial structure for 
government counterpart financial support. 
(iii)  Analyze PPP options leading to the optimum project structure. 
(iv)  Undertake risk assessment, including recommendations on the risk allocation 
between the public and private sectors. 
(v)  Draft prequalification and bidding documents, including the PPP agreement and 
procurement plan, and also prepare an information memorandum for the project. 
(vi)  Engage in consultation aimed at attracting private sector interest and finalizing 
the project structure. 
(vii)  Assist  during  the  prequalification  of  private  sponsors  (or  private  bidders), 
including  evaluation  of  prequalification  applications,  prebid  meetings,  and 
consultations as required; and during the bidding, include evaluation of technical 
and financial proposals from the prequalified private sponsors (bidders). 
(viii)  Assist during negotiations with the preferred private sponsor and finalize the PPP 
agreement.3 
 
9.  Refinements to the above, based on the TA scope, are possible once the consulting 
firms submit their technical proposals. 
 
                                                
3  This may include various forms of incentives provided by the government for the project.
